												Broken, lacking depth, arcade rubbish. The words that spring to mind having now played 8 hrs since launch. That the developers have labelled this a simulation and imagine it is worthy as a release candidate beggars belief. Pick one of 4 rig types that you are limited to carrying when you are fishing, pick one of four baits that you are limited to carrying and that's your terminal tackle sorted, seriously? Where do I adjust boilie buoyancy, hair length, my shock leader, and link length, pick hook type and size independent of the chosen rig. Where are the method feeders, carp poles, marker floats, bait boats, baiting sticks, feeder rods. Where are the oils for soaking boilie's, the pva stringers and bags, and the selection of groundbaits and particles for the spod rod. Why the hell are worms, luncheon meat, casters and maggots awol in a fishing game that features roach bream, tench and carp. Where is the window dressing such as alternate clothing, bivvies, bite alarms, landing nets, et al. Everything I would expect to see at launch from a title labelled an accurate simulation of European Fishing.Then there are the game mechanics that are present but not working correctly, even the basics such as fish control and landing glitch frequently, fish that run for 20 meters under the bank, line retrieval that bears no relationship to what I am actually doing or seeing, fish that become stuck under the tip of my rod, fish ai that is unaffected by wind direction, then there are the constant stream of bites, how I wish that fishing for carp and cats was so easy irl.I could go on but if you do not have a clear picture of this title yet, there is little point. It clearly has potential, graphically it looks good, but as a simulation of angling it stinks, as a release candidate it stinks, it is just not good enough; at best it is a shallow, broken, arcade game.

Early Access Review
								Ok, as a mature gamer and a UK course fisherman, i was intrigued the moment i saw this title. Mainly because it wasnt based on lure fishing for bass, which it seems 99% of fishing games are.  The first thing that struck me on playing it was the beautifull training lake, it was a while before i even cast a rod out as i was strolling round the lake in awe of the lush scenery. I struggled a bit at first with the fishing mechanics, but soon got used to it, and with practice it became very natural and pretty dam realistic. Im so glad i stuck with it for a couple of hours and got to grips with the controls, because now after several updates and much practice i am enjoying this game more than ever and would highly recommend it to anyone.The most impressive aspect of this project i feel, is the direction its heading in, although the updates arent super regular when the do hit they bring massive improvements and content. Phase 6 added a massive new lake, boss fish, landing net mechanics, a tackle shop and much more. All of the additions were well implemented and brought a lot more structure to the game. Unfortunatly i have now bought all the best tackle and saved up quite a bit of money for future tackle shop items. But the fact that its the first game i check everyday when im looking at whats been updated is testament to its genius. With the promise of Tench and float fishing equipment to come my mouth is watering!There are still some bugs of course as it is early access, but the devs are active enough and seem to be working on them. There is also online multiplyer now which works but is still very much in Alpha. I truly hope this gets the support and backing it deserves as it is, by far, the best fishing game ive ever played, already and theres still content to come. My advice to the devs on this one is please keep up the good work and keep heading in the direction your are... oh and hurry up with my Tench :POverall the good massively outweighs the bad and in my opinion is already a worthwile purchase.

Early Access Review
								[Early Access - Phase 5] UPDATEYES! You finally have a sense of freedom in freedom fishing. Game mechanics feel good, though I feel like now I'm throwing so far I might hit mountains the far distance. I liked the triple spinning wheel bug as well, sadly it is going to be fixed.[Early Access - Phase 3] UPDATEWhat I like:- Casting is a lot easier. I didn't find myself trying over and over again to get a goot shot like in phase 1, and I didn't have to move mymouse all across the table (mouse mat was sufficient :)).- Improved visuals. Some of the things that annoyed me about the first release was some basic but unrealistic/immersion breaking visuals like a rope-thick line and a very wobbly fishing pole. These have been fixed now, at least to some extent. The line is pretty good, or perfect in terms of thickness now and the pole has just about the right stiffness to it. I still experience motor-boating and pole glitches kind of often, but the basics are a lot better.- Character feedback. Another issue I had that has now been improved on is the characters feedback to the force of the fish and so on, when you are fishing. It is very pleasing, and I didn't find my self getting thrown off by the characters reactions this time - big +.- New features. The fish variations are great and I managed to catch a few during my testing of the game. Leader boards are great. Adds a lot more to the game and actually makes it worthwhile to play the game in its current state. I didn't manage to go too far up the rankings but it was a lot more fun and exciting to catch something and see how far it will get you.What I could see improved:- The fish AI. It was a lot better than first time I played, but I still experienced fish going from 10-80yds in a matter of seconds when fishing from some spots (especially the little closed spot without a lot of room, had issues). The fish also seemed to not care about swimming through landscape as I frequently saw fish going directly throw rocks/trees and sometimes into the land/road/path on the other side of the lake.- The force on the pole when having a hook is ok, but the line is not always acting accordingly. I frequently experienced a pole arced and bent like a bow, while the line acted as is if no force at all was being aplied to it.What I didn't like:- Reeling/catching fish seems to be bugged sometimes as I have found myself reeling in for a solid 10 minutes two times in a row at the same fishing spot without anything major happening to the yard indicator/other. I frequently feel like having no idea whats going on underneath the water. Like if I'm catching a fish and it's almost in reach (5-10ish)yds I'm just able to keep reeling in without anything happening. The line should be rather short at that point, but it feels like it's extended by 100 miles underneath the water. Also while reeling, at times when I was not able to pull the fish towards me (maybe extended the line underneath the water) I was still able to steer the fish to the left or right which makes no sense. While reeling I often wondered if the game had bugged out, if I was doing something totally wrong etc. Didn't feel very responsive. I think the latest updates have been good and have improved the game in areas where improvement were needed, but some fundamentals are still flawed. Pleased with this update :)-----------------------------------[Early Access - Phase 1] ORIGINALI understand the game is in early access, but I just think it is lacking in too many aspects, and I think the developers should have waited a bit before releasing it to the public and accepting your money.What you get to see in this early access is basically a few tutorials and trials, so you can get a feel for how the game and the mechanics are going to be implemented. This is fine, it is content-wise what they claimed it to be. I would be satisfied with this amount of content, if it wasn't because of the bare basics of the game not being very well implemented at all yet. For a dedicated fishing simulator, it doesn't do a very good job at simulating what real fishing feels like. On top of that the mechanics felt clunky, the visuals didn't feel right and the main point of the game (fishing) felt really awkward, unreal and unresponsive.Problems with the visuals:- The fishing line looks thicker than the pole itself, and I know it has to be easy to see on screen but there has to be a better way. The line also seems a lot heavier than an actual line (which is as light as a snowflake flowing in the wind), when you look at how it reacts with the physics currently in the game.- The fishing pole looks way too rubbery/elastic compared to a real pole. Very wobly :). Like if you shake your hand a bit, it might go all bananes.- The tension on the fishing line is the worst part about the visual issues. Very immersion breaking. When I have a fish on the line, the string tension is very unrealistic. It doesn't matter if the fish is 40 yards away or 10 yards, if I'm reeling in or being idle, the string looks all the same. I get no real feel for how far away the fish is, how hard it is pulling and so on - other than the numbers I see on the screen. I found this to be very immersion breaking, it didn't feel at all like I was having a hook!Problems with the game (fishing).- When I'm reeling in I have no idea what is going on underneath the water. Sometimes I was reeling in for a long long while, but the yard indicator stayed the same, and there was no other visual feedback. I didn't know if the game had glitched out and my reeling didn't do anything, or if the fish had managed to extend my line by another 100 yeards underneath the water for me to reel in afterwards. I think it would be nice to get some sort of idea of how long your line is, and not just how far away the fish is. Because this just felt so weird when I couldn't feel the force in my pole, and just stood there reeling in for minutes from a minor hook.- The fish (1 kind in this early alpha) is very athletic, it goes from one end of the lake and back in a matter of seconds. It does this for a while, then suddenly stops. Like it spend all of its energy traveling so fast from one end of the lake to the other and then suddenly colapses. It also bites the hook very frequently, so the food must me scarse around this lake. :)- As mentioned earlier you get almost no visual feedback or cues from the fishing pole, the string or the fishing guy. When you get a hook the pole, string, and the guy - they all just act as if there was no force pulling in the other end of the line. In contrast to this, the fish is going crazy underneath the water as I mentioned earlier. It just feels so unrealistic and weird. This would be okay as a side game in GTA or something like that, but this coming from a dedicated fishing simulator was disappointing.Problems with the controls:- Something feels really awkward about the controls, I have a hard time pointing out exactly what is causing this.- I think one part is the mouse sensitivity. You turn very slowly while the pole is very wobly and when you throw the line out into the water I almost have to move my hand all across the desk to get a good shot.- The throwing part does not feel consistent. Sometimes I get a really nice shot, but the next time I do the eactly same movement (with minor differences ofc), the bait may end up only 11 yards away and in another direction. It just didn't feel right.All in all, I think the basic features should have been better implemented when releasing a paid early access of a dedicated fishing game with this amount of content. I don't see a point for anyone to get it yet, UNLESS you are very interested in fishing and can't wait to get a glimpse of what this new game will look like.[Deleted the last 5 paragraphs to make room for the phase 3 review update].

								EARLY ACCESS REVIEW BASED ON PHASE 4 RELEASE.Dovetail Games Fishing is one of those games that come to mind as unique. Or maybe even niche. Because the people who actually do fish, will be outside doing actual fishing. It makes you wonder why to even make a simulation based on it? Well to be fair to DTG, they hit the nail on the head. The game itself is based around a lake which you now, have complete control over. You can now walk and fish in different spots, you can now, change your lures, and you can even put your rod down!The attention to detail is amazing as the whole atmosphere projects a warm sunny summers day morning and the ambient sounds of birds chirping away to the splashing of over excited fish is simply sublime.To their advantage, is that the developers of the game at Dovetail, enjoy fishing and do it often. So the game is being made by fishers for fishers. I myself am not a fisher. But to play this game is to encapsulate what I do enjoy. A nice relaxing morning or afternoon in the middle of a green area.I would recommend this game based on "Phase One", and this review is based on "Phase Four". As such, I'm still going to recommend it. Quality. Absolute quality!

												This is not going to show as an "Early Access review" but as far as I'm concerned it should be. DTG pushed the release on this (Nov 2), perhaps to try and counter Fishing Planet. It was a mistake because the bugs and problems with this are numerous. Some of the glaringly obvious:-- Fish that SLIDE sideways, they don't swim at all. Sure, their tails wag but that's the model, not the AI. They almost teleport they move so fast sometimes. Even the biggest fish around the 40kg mark, bounce and slide around like a Smartie in a blender. I've written script for fish and rotating them "naturally" is a pretty simple task. Adding proper inertia and momentum is a little trickier but certainly doable too.- The casting is not bad (with practise) but a 50m cast, to the opposite side of a lake, which looks to be 150-200m away, is up on the bank. 2 winds of the reel and you're back in the middle of the lake at 30m or so. In some cases you can't even see where your gear is until you bring it back to under 30m.- Reel winding is shocking. A 5:1 reel, with zero tension, should be bringing in close to a metre of line per turn. You can literally turn the handle 50 times and get back a metre of line. I made this observation in the forums and was told it's an "audio" problem because I mentioned I should at least be hearing the clutch slipping. Did they answer about not being able to wind in with zero tension or that my reel acts like it's  1:25 ratio?  Not even mentioned.- Fish snap off, for no reason, in some places on some maps. Can't even be bothered reporting it.- The fish "fight" is only really differentiated by time. A BIG fish in RL can and will run for 10's of metres non-stop, sheer power. Smaller fish dart and dance. Some of these 40kg monsters swim like a Goldfish and you get frustratingly stuck with a bouncing yo-yo fish, 7m out and 5m deep, going nowhere. Some smaller fish, where your breaking strain is 3 times that of fish, simply "lock up" 10m out and just pull against the line. You cannot wind them in, you have to pump and wind like it's a 10kg carp.- 15lb Touchdown line is borked. Unlimited drag. Max it to 100% and skulldrag your fish straight in. I mentioned this is a pretty serious exploit because XP and TP (the currency) is linked to catches. There are also live tournaments against real players and anyone NOT fishing 15lb will lose - obviously. Answer from devs. "It's up to you if you use it or not".- Tournament scores do not update in RT, in some cases not at all.- "Boss" fish are able to be caught one after another. I caught 5 in a row, from the same location, using the same gear, line, bait. everything.- My favourite. You can catch a "Boss" fish (all independently named) on Rod #1 and while you're taking it off the hook, Rod #2 goes off and presto..... same Boss fish. I've caught 3 in a row on this, others have caught the same Boss 5 times in a row.- FPS is capped at 30fps. Yes folks. UE4 engine, PC game, CAPPED at 30fps.- AMD users are suffering all kinds of glitching, gamma, flickering and crashes. Devs say it's AMD and/or Epic (UE4). Anyone who playes the multitude of UE4 games out there (Ark is one of the most popular) knows that AMD cards are NOT suffering this across the board.- VERY short gameplay. In 40 hours, much of it playing the broken tournaments, I am nearly maxed out and own almost everything. - The gear. Some of it is so similar (or lacking in gameplay neccessity) that it makes accumulation pointless. BUT, you need to buy item #1 to be able to buy item #2 so... accumulate you do.Look. I've had enough of this, I've annoyed myself, sounding all whiney and sooky. I could go on but just the attitudes of devs to problems you officially document is pretty poor. A whole lot of pseudo-surprise, "we'll look into it", "our testing didn't do that"  etc... all the while telling you they're working on more content, and given it's Dovetail Games, it'll be mostly DLC.For now. IF it's on special it might be worth a look because they MAY address these issues. $20 for 40 hours is probably not too bad so I'll not complain too much more.IF this had been an Early Access title my review would be completely different and my tolerance for errors would be much, much higher. But when you release broken titles... Shame.5/10It get's an up.... Just. It is fishing, it's kinda relaxing and looks reasonable. It will be good for awhile but you'll run out of fun very quickly.

												Firstly the closest I have ever come to actually fishing, is this game! I knew nothing of fishing or it's intricacies until I ventured onto this game. My Husband and Son have been plaing this game for a while, and to be honest, it is great viewing as well as playing. But I wanted to have a go myself and see just what all the fishy fun was about. Cue my guy, Wilhelm. Wilhelm is going great guns. He has 3 rods; Kenny 'Fishing' Powers, Ray Bream-ero and Doug Heffer-Carp. The delight in pulling in a fish that takes a while to land is thrilling and just so satifying. An Acheivement that is as unexpected as it is awesome. So about the game; well, go through the tutorial or Acadamy to learn the basics- if you know nothing as I did then this is the  place where your fishy education begins. Then feel free to go and complete the challenges you have unlocked, or free fishing and just enjoy the game's beautiful ambience. The graphics, the fish detail, the weather, the sounds within this game are just fantastic. Immersive and peaceful. The gentle plopping of fish as they leap out of the water, or the sound of the wind as it begins to rise (shadow detail also shows the tree shadows moving in the wind) or the pitter patter of rain. I just simply love playing. There are levels to go up, a skill tree for tackle and bait. Earning Tackle Points as you catch fish, complete challenges and finish tournaments (the latter has either a live daily match or in game AI tournaments) means that you can develop your fisher-person to be the best in every field or go for one particular area of expertise. There is nothing quite like landing your first big carp, or first fish, but the ultimate (next to Boss Fish) is catching a HUGE Catfish!!!! Notes on gameplay: -* Have patience. Learn the tension gradients that are applicable to your tackle- losing a fish that you have spent 5 minutes reeling in only for it to get away can be gutting. Learn your rod's capability* Equip your net at 4yrds or less to get the instant land- anything above 4 and you wont be able to manouvre the net to catch the fish. * Screenshots are addictive- But awesome to show off those catches that made you feel proud. Please do take a peek at mine if you would like to see the look of the fish. * Character choice is limited- but there is no need to have a full on customisation option when all you see mostly is the back of your character. * Learn about the rigs, the best bait for that rig and go fishing where the fish you want to catch hang out. * Read the Boss Fish Menu and descriptions they are awesome* Don't be disheartened Rome wasn't built in a day and neither is the best tacklebox- take your time and have fun with the game. * Make as many fish related puns as you can- this is a source of never ending amusment. Life is but a Bream :-) * Slow life down for an hour! Take the small joy of a days fishing and be at peace. No traffic, no bosses moaning, no stress- just one rod at a time, one fishy at a time Enjoy and 'Carp-i' Diem ;-P AngelDelight81 xx

												This was a great game to begin with, although it had its issues. Graphics are not great even on Ultra. Casting took a bit of time to learn but not that hard. The baits that you carry with you in game do not hold their descriptions, only their name, so it is hard to remeber what hook it goes best with and what fish to target. The biggest killer for me was adding AUTO-NETTING. This took the thrill out of the game for me. Before auto-netting, I was able to really battle fish to the edge of the lake and then try and aim my net whilst tilting my rod. Had me in all sorts of weird positions haha but it was fun. I logged in today, noticed auto net feature, and had to wait several times with a fish at my feet and no way to net it because the games decided the fish was not "tired" enough. Now, the game is boring and repetitive. There was some resistance to the auto-net feature on the forums, and this was ignored by the developers. They should have allowed auto-netting as an OPTION, not as the only way to play. Well done devs, you killed this game for me. Do not bother buying if you want action, its no longer there.UPDATE 20/Oct/2016:After not receiving an answer on the forums about a possible re-implementation of the manual-netting option, I contacted the support team at DTG. Scott from DTG answered me quite quickly and was very professional. Unfortunately, it seems while the team is considering the re-introduction of this much needed game mechanic, there is nothing further to announce on the topic. This means I am shelving the game. Without the action and the thrill that manual-netting brings, I am afraid that no further updates will make a difference towards my enjoyment of the game. I would have liked to continue playing whilst other updates were being worked on, but there is no point if I cant have fun. This post is not meant to be inflammatory, it only aims to provide people who feel the same way an opportunity to think about whether or not this game is worth their money. If you enjoy a good arcade fishing game, then pick this up because you will get some enjoyment out of it. If you want a simulator that gives you more options rather than taking them away, perhaps you should wait until the manual-netting option is re-introduced and is set in stone, at which point my review of this game will be positive. If you find yourself getting bored really fast, chances are its the arcade style netting mechanic.As it stands I find myself getting increasingly frustrated when I have a tiny roach sitting at the edge of a lake, mean-mugging me and laughing at me, behind the safety of the auto-netting mechanic, while it builds mud castles at my feet before it gets tired enough for me to automatically pick up. It makes me feel like tenderly kissing it on the head before launching the little bas#%!$ across the water of the lake like a flatrock.In any case, I would once again like to thank Scott from DTG support for listening to my reasoning and getting back to me so quickly. If you are not getting any responses on the STEAM forum, give the support team a try, as they do listen and may be able to let you know how long you may be waiting before an aspect on the game you currently dislike may be rectified. So to conclude, if you are after a decent arcade fishing experience by all means pick this game up. If you think auto-netting will affect your enjoyment, wait until it manual-netting is re-introduced. It may take 6 months, a year, who knows really, but the game might be cheaper by then.

												I think most of the negative reviews come from bad experiences pre- and early launch. A lot of the bugs and issues have been fixed now, so I can definetely recommend this game. It may not be the best fishing simulator, but it is still an enjoyable game.A few positive points:- An in-game shop with a very extensive set of possibilities for your tackle boxes: reels, rods, lines, hooks, baits...- Several fish species: multiple carp species, catfish, bream, roach...- different bed types: silt, gravel and weed. You have to keep this in mind when choosing your hooks and bait.- Enjoyable and relaxing ambient sound.- The thrill to keep fishing to get to the top of the leaderboards, and/or set a personal best. There's also your profile with statistics and fish species and bosses you have already/not caught. Each lake has its own unique bosses.- There are also online tournaments, tutorials, AI competitions and minigames which all reward in-game currency and xp.Negative points:- A few graphical bugs.- The time to wait for a fish to bite is sometimes too long.- Some players find casting too hard. I find it easy (after a bit of practice).In general this is a very good game, but for some people this may be too expensive because you can get bored soon.

A good enough concept; graphics are reasonably solid, equipment is diverse, and there are good sized fishing locales which can be roamed pretty freely. Cooperative play works well in my limited experience playing this way, however be aware that another player can stand literally on top of you, completelyt obscuring your view and making it almost impossible to see, and therein do, anything at all--something as ironic as it is nonsensical, given that another player is cannot, supposedly, fish the same spot as you concomitantly ('Pegged' areas become player unique territories once pegged by any single player). This just one example of how poor game design makes Euro fishing contravene its own intentions. And logic.Euro Fishing is ultimately  rendered frustrating and not really worth playing owing to bugs, and some extremely poor mechanics--specifically the striking and netting features. Both are awkward, clunky,  drudgerous  and generally difficult to negotiate with a keyboard & mouse setup. With respect to the former,  you have to really slide backwards with your mouse very quickly (and quite excessively)  quite a distance to succesfully sink in a strike which may or may not bug out irregardless of line tension. It's not easy to get right, and Lag spikes compund this problem considerably.The netting mechanic is, quite simply, spectacularly and singularly awful, and needs to be rebuilt from the ground up or done away with entirely. Because you cannot simueltaneously control your rod (with fish on) and the net at the same time, it is extremely difficult to orientate either so they allign, which is what you need to do in order to succesfully land a fish. What5 this tends to result in  ( along with many, many lost fish) is aa kind of rage-inspiring comedy of errors to the tune of:Reel in fish a little closer to the bank. Pick up net. Fish takes out more line, making iut impossible to net fish.  Drop net. Reel in fish a little. Pick up net. Net not at correct angle in order to allign with fish. Drop net. Repeat x3. Get frustrated. Attempt to skulldrag fish in as close to the bank as possible in order to compensate for abysmal ( and entirely not sensitive enough) netting mechanic. Drag suddenly gooes from not tight enough to too tight. Line breaks, lose fish.And over and over ad nauseam.Perhaps the system is easier to negotiate with a controller. I have not played Euro fishing this way.In any case, the game feels rushed, malformed , and  compared to something like fishing planet, is more annoying than it is enjoyable--additionally, there's not enough that's great about about it to allow one to look past its considerable and multivariate problems.Score:3/10.

content:

Preface: This review is a "compare & contrast" with another popular fishing title released around the same time, Fishing Planet. I like both and think they're both quality titles, but they do different things well and will satisfy different tastes. This review is meant to help you decide which one you might prefer. I wrote a similar review for FP, and will update both when FP comes out of early access.+Enjoyable, pleasant environments you can actually exploreDTG's Euro Fishing really nails the old adage "There's more to fishing than the fish." The different lakes have a real sense of place, and they're all beautiful locations that are a pleasure to be in. This is helped by the ability to actually walk around each location and fish from different areas. Being able to explore and discover your own favorite spots adds a lot to the feeling of authenticity. While Fishing Planet may have a greater diversity in locations and environments, only a few tiny areas in each place are open to you. +Nice photo-op payoffs after landing a fishAfter landing each fish, DTG's Euro Fishing gives you a little photo-op with your catch. This might sound silly, but it actually adds a lot to the game by providing a sense of closure to each catch and a sense of personality to the fish. It's why Euro Fishing is one of only 2 games I ever bother to screencap (the other being Kerbal Space Program).+The fish look really goodThe fish themselves are well done, and thanks to the photo-ops you get some time to really look at them. Fishing Planet's fish look good, but not nearly this good (and w/o a good photo-op moment, you never get a clear look at them anyways).+Real MultiplayerYou can play multiplayer matches with other people on the same lake. FP, while ostensibly an MMO, is so highly instanced its multiplayer is basically a chatroom added to a single-player game. That said, both communities are very friendly and helpful, and FP's multiplayer features haven't been fully implemented yet.+Actual casting mechanicsThis is a blessing and a curse. Casting is an actual skill to master in DTG's Euro Fishing, which makes it satisfying when done well and frustrating when it impedes you from catching fish. Landing the perfect cast to catch a unique fish you know is hiding in *that* weed bed feels like an accomplishment. Casting your rig into your foot over and over again for 10 minutes gets aggravating. FP's casting is much easier, but is nothing more than a power meter.+Real "unique" fishMost areas have a number of unique named fish. Since IRL people fish stocked, managed lakes where you must release your catch, some fish gain names and reputations (one famous carp even received a burial from anglers after it died of old age). These unique fish are well-implemented, and catching one is a fun accomplishment. They go a long way toward adding personality to each location. FP's unique fish don't have nearly this much to them, and seem to be just very large specimens of the species.-Not much variety of environmentsAll of the locations in DTG's Euro Fishing are stocked lakes. While you can walk around and explore them all, they all lend themselves to the same kind of fishing. Compare that with FP, which has a much greater diversity of location types.-Not much variety of fishing stylesDTG's Euro Fishing currently has one kind of fishing: ledgering. This is a rather sedentary form of catching fish, where a weight holds your line to the lake bed and you wait for a fish to pick up your hook & bait. Float fishing will be added in a future free DLC, but currently you only get to do one kind of fishing: ledgering for carp & coarse fish. Fishing Planet supports both float and spin fishing. Spin fishing in particular is a much more active method of angling, and FP even recognizes different techniques and styles of presenting the lure.-Not much variety of fishLake fishing for carp & other coarse fish is the focus of DTG's Euro Fishing. No trout, no pike, no crappie, no bass, no salmon etc.-Not much equipmentEuro Fishing's selection of gear is pretty small, and the descriptions do a mediocre job of explaining what it all does. Fishing Planet has a dizzying amount of gear, which supports its greater variety of target fish, locations and fishing styles.-Landing mechanic is a messNetting & landing fish is barely functioning at the moment. It beats FP's landing mechanic (it has none), but it won't take much for FP to release something far superior.-Mediocre water effectsA fishing game really needs better water. It doesn't cripple the game, but it doesn't compare well to the water in Fishing Planet. Considering how much time you spend staring at it, I'd have hoped for something more convincing.-Weak NPE (new player experience)Euro Fishing's tutorial is mediocre, but it actually has one (which is more than can be said for FP). However, it does has a really helpful series of videos to help those completely new to coarse fishing. Unfortunately, the lack of a wiki will hamper those who want to dive deep into the game. Early Access Review
								With Phase 6, I think it's even clearer than before that this game is going to turn out to be something good. It started out as a very solid, albeit bare, fishing game, but with every update features are added, and mechanics are dialed in some more. The team seems to be listening intently and working hard to put out as much win in every update as they possibly can.This update brings a working multiplayer mode, which consists of the training lake (only) and up to 4 (iirc) other people fishing. There is a (half-working atm) chat function that lets players on a lake share tips and brag about big catches, which is very cool (if I see someone landing many fish, I tend to ask what bait they're using). Using chat while on a peg is problematic, though, due to the hotkeys for keyboard controls not being disabled while focus is on the chat box. My whole peg has been closed many times because I tried to chat, heh. The chat box also has a bad habit of ignoring sentences. Other than that, multiplayer is definitely working and enjoyable.The quality of the fishing experience gets better with every update (imo), and the team behind it stay on the forums, getting feedback and making changes based on what they see and hear. Force feedback on a 360 controller is much improved, and the controls, for the most part, make sense. However, general consensus is that a mouse gives much better control of power for accurate casting. You carry a tackle box and up to three fishing rods, and gain new gear by spending money earned from catching fish. Lake bed conditions and other factors make the careful choosing of bait and gear an important part of the process, as well as knowing a good spot or two. One can have 3 fishing rods baited and in the water at a time, and alarms on each rod (audible + light) let you know if something is nibbling and running with anything.There are occasional bugs (flying fish, SPOD-arm until restart), but nothing too bad. After the features get hammered out better I am sure that the few there are will be dealt with accordingly.If you like fishing and video games, this is a pretty safe bet. Just don't expect it to be a polished experience at this time.

												I was a little apprehensive buying this game, due to the reviews, but I'm glad I gave it a shot.  Haven't had a single crash or glitch since I've been playing.Overall, this game scratches the fishing sim itch very well. Haven't had this much fun since the original Trophy Bass from Sierra back in the day. The tackle machanics are simple and it's easy to gain the tackle points to unlock the gear you want to specifically target fish. The dynamic weather and changes in fishing pace really add some depth: you're not going to be catching them quickly all the time, and you have to consider what's in your tackle box and your surroundings.Landing a fish is fairly straightforward, and I think that's been my only real disappointment. After a while, the bigger fish will just give up and swim straight to you, so I imagine tweaking the AI would be needed to fix that. Catching a 40lb carp or 60lb catfish should involve more than just holding the rod tip high and keeping the reel butting pressed down.Casting seems to be another bone of contention with a lot of folks. Give yourself the time to learn it and it's easy. If you can crank up your mouse sensitivity, it helps a lot. Between the short, flipping casts and the long casts, you can cover any  area you want to near the peg you're fishing.A few tips if you find yourself stuck with some of the common problems:-You can't select a rod, change rig or put your rod down unless you're standing close to the edge of the peg-If progression seems slow, try free fishing at some of the later-stage lakes. The individual fish can make you way more tackle points than a tourney-Casting just takes practice. Don't get frustrated, make sure you're not underneath trees or in an area where you're constantly hitting the opposite bank-This game is somewhat resource intensive, keep that in mind if you're on an older PC. Might need to adjust a few things for smooth framerateIf you're looking for a fishing game, this one is hard to beat currently. It's relaxing, enjoyable and definitely exciting when it needs to be.

								Are you an angler? If yes, this is your game. If I have to compare this game with the others from the past, this work is the most definitive masterpiece from all times. It aims for the relaxing side of lakeside amusement. No need to reel in to catch  your bass or pike, just use your wits to select your most effective rig, choose your most attracting bait, make a precise throw and wait for the bite. If everything's in harmony, you don't have to wait too long. The bite alarm will go off, and there you go... The fish fights, kicks, struggles as long as her energy keeps her moving. Is she big? Well mate, she will make you sweat because the rod behaviour and the the line tension are as realistic as in real life. It's not a rare thing, when you fight with the fish for 20 or 30 minutes. Keep the tension downs for a sec and off she goes... Your fish swims away like a lightening, and you stare at your empty hook thinking: "How's that possible?" On the other hand. If you're the better one: your catch tires out, lying exhausted on top of the water , you're still have to use your net to catch you prey. One wrong move, and the sleeping beauty awakes and off the hook... In short terms: This game is awesome, even, if it's in early acces stage. I just can't do anything else, only to recommend it!

												This is a great game, very addictive but with some work needed.First the good,I like the fact you dont have to grind it out just to use some good tackle. when I walk into a fishing shop im not asked "what level are you?" ehh! the lakes look really well, digger lake is my fav' with all its nice we pegs snuggled away for me to find. No doubt ill keep euro fishing installed as Im always saying "just one more fish" before im done today. Now, the bad (sorry it has to be done).The game feels very, alpha still. there are a load of areas that need tweeks. ill start with the tackle, ive found the strongest line isnt the 25lb but the 15lb SUBLine (Stalking section). with the 15lb I just set drag to 100% and pull in anything that I hook up without a single danger of the line going tight and snaping. Of course the down side is if your fish goes real loose it will come off easy, or when you get a bite you may loose the fish before you even get to strike. this I dont mind though as its just like getting small hits as with real fishing. The rate of catching BIG fish is un-real, its like match fishing for roach and hauling in big carp and cats. The landing net just about works but again, it still works just needs more time spent tweeking, like most areas of the game.So I would say this game is totally worth its price. A BIG factor im worried about though is the leveling, once on level 20 thats it. no need for any more XP. The game is JUST about ready for release and no more and I think the Dev's know that. 								EDIT** Since a dev popped in here and apparently can't read I feel that I might want to clarify my review for those others who I guess also can't read like the dev.  I AM NOT REVIEWING THE GAMEPLAY!  I AM WARNING FELLOW AMERICANS THIS MIGHT NOT BE FOR THEM AT THIS POINT IN TIME.  This is for those who read reviews more carefully than store pages because we all know how stuff gets left out and details omitted on the store pages. This is for those who are looking for an American fishing game and I am here to tell you it is not.  I also in my original review below have doubts that there will ever be something for Americans. This is a very simple logical result of looking at how long it has taken them to get this far. They are not yet close to having carp done. In order to do lets say, northwest American Salmon fishing it would require at least an equal amount of time because locations, gear, everything is different. To do even catfish which they could borrow alot of stuff from the english carp world it would take months. Now I am not programmer but it doesn't take a rocket scientist to see if it takes them over half a year to do 2 fish species with a few sub-species thrown in, then it will take a simular but not as long time to do a single other species. Does this game play ok?? IDK I don't play it anymore and I couldn't tell you because i am not English and I wouldn't fish for a carp if you paid me money to.  But if they ever do add any American species I will be the first MF'er to let yall know.At the moment I cannot recommend this game due to one simple reason. The fishing is foreign. They do plan on having more fish species but for now its just carp and bream. Carp is a throw away fish that noone wants to catch in the US because they are full of bones, eat terrible and are considered the garbage of fish here in the US. Guess English folk love them but here they are junk. Bream is a fish your kid catches here in the US while your fishing for "real" fish. 												I really enjoyed Cabela's Big Game Hunter, and tried Eurofishing looking for the wilderness ambient and fishing/hunting strategy. I am enjoying the game, but I must say that casting by moving the mouse and clicking the right button at the same time is messy and inpractical. Anyway, by adjusting the mouse sensibility (middle position) I found that it is a lot easier. Still, I wish it could be done in other way.Lakes are great. Those available are located in various countrys, and tough the lakes themselves are fictional, they strongly resembles the real lakes of those areas.My main complain is that you don't need much strategy for fishing. I mean, you mainly search for a nice peg, or go stalking. Fish move through the day from one area to another. But there's nothing that you can do to catch a certain species (well, except for the kind of bait you use), or going for real big fish or lake bosses . I would like the game to be more rewarding for the patient, strategic player, but devs tend to make this games more rewarding for begginers, in hope that they won't put down it due to initial boredom. The devs had stated that they are adding float fishing for free in the next weeks, so I hope the game will grow and get better. The store is a bit small, I would like to have more items to buy, including clothes, customized equipment, and so. Oh, and Multiplayer is ok, but is not my thing.Last, but not least: I feel that the game is not very optimized. It won't run fluent in the typical laptop. My GeForce 840N doesn't handle it very nicely. You better check the requirements.As a clonclusion... a very nice game, **if you like these kind of games**. I am in hope that the game community will grow and that the devs will create exciting new scenarios and items.

												Best Fishing Game I have played in a long timeSo let me say that this is one of the best fishing games I have played in a long time.  The game has issues.  Hopefully they can fix them.  So if it has issues then why is it the best I've played in a long time?That would be because fishing games aren't made often and when they are they are very arcade now.  No multiplayer and no tournaments for multiplayer.  So what about this game?  Okay I'll tell you the goods and bads and leave it at that.The goods--Good looking Environment.  This includes the water.  I have mine set to highest setting and the water looks great.-Fish graphics are really great.  Fish look very real and are done very well-Fish are swimming in the water you are fishing in.  Yup there are fishing swimming around that you have to hope come across your bait.  The most I went without a bite was 20 minutes, but its also because I didn't move.  It's not arcade feeling and feels like real fishing because of waiting longer times sometimes than others.-This is Euro fishing.  I did't think I would like it because I like to bass fish and such, but I was really wrong.  Catching fish off a peg is great.  You put your rods in the pegs and wait and then hear your line screaming and the peg screaming too.  It can be intense sometimes.-Hook and bait size matter.  These things will make the biggest difference on what size fish you can catch.  Too big of hook and bait and a 8 pound fish cant eat it.  Although they make your peg light up sometimes trying to.-Rod bend is really nice and your player is graphically sound-You see fish jumping out of the water or bubbles where they are feeding-Huge selection of rods, reels, and line.  Bait selection is pretty good and or amazing for bottom fishing.  Since its not bass the amount is good.-This is a 3D game and lake.  You get to literally walk every inch of the lakes and can fish with one rod or use a peg with 3 rods.  This is not that â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ fishing planet game where you are stuck in one â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ section of a non existant lake or river.-They hold tournaments all the time and you can play solo tournaments-MULTIPLAYER!!!!!  You get to fish with friends and watch them reel fish in!!! Holy crap and even can see their peg light up and hear their line screaming out.  -You get to walk all over the lake and decide where to fish-Good amount of lakes to choose from although you will be basically fishing the last 2 lakes which have the biggest fish.  -BOSS FISH!  There are boss fish in game and make you want to fish all the lakes and even for small fish to try and catch these rare guys.  They go from 2 pounds all the way up to 100.-You can use 3 rods and even use a bait rod to throw bait into the water over your current bait to help get bites.-You can fish night or day and can host a session or join someone elses-Easy to pick up and learn.-Different types of things to fish on.  Gravel, Silt, Weeds-Weeds around lakes are obvious and only a idiot can't find them-Love the netting system.  People are idiots and don't know how to net the fish so they complained aâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ton and now they are making a automatic netting system.  Really hope they allow us to use the old manual system.  It makes it more realistic and fun.-Casting system is really good and if you dont do it right you wont be casting far.  Easy to learn, hard to master-Pretty RealisticTHE BADS-Here we go-Tension and drag system is not working correctly in game yet.  Its pretty bad, but even then its still fun to catch fish in this game.  Makes me wonder how this company could screw this up since its literally a core part of the game mechanics-Rod, reel, line make no difference in catching fish.  You can use the starter rod setup and catch the 100 pound cat in game.  Just have to keep your tension at 16 and dont break it off and wait for fish to tire.  Then you get him in-Fish seem to be on a rail system when caught.  Almost like they aren't swimming.  You really can't influence how the fish moves or which way.  Although if you hold your rod far right or left they do seem to move that way eventually.-No player made tournaments yet.  LAME!-The fish really don't effect the water.  yea they jump and make a splash, but when hooked they wont do that.  They make small splashes when close, but thats about it.-No in game voice chat just message system-The company doesn't seem to be worrying about the really important aspects of the game and just fixing small stuff that are being complained the most about.  They really need to pull their heads out of their butts and fix the tension and drag issues as well as the fish on a rail system and not really swimming when caught.  Although they said they are fixing rod bend so we will see what that is.Conclusion-Although the bads seem really bad I still have a lot of fun with this game.  I have been fishing since I was very young and I have played very few fishing games that made me enjoy it.  This game has and I even meet some new players on there and we fish together.  Its a great game and if they can fix some core issues it will be a absolute beast in the gaming/electronic fishing genre.  This game has so much promise its crazy.  I know its weird to say that about a game thats out and being bought.  If you see it on sale its a must buy in my opinions.  I paid the full 20 and think it was well worth it.  They will be adding a new lake soon with Pike and lure fishing for the pike.  So I am really looking forward to that.
